conclusion: To determine when objects A and B are farthest apart, analyze their velocity-time (v-t) graphs.
The distance between the two objects at any given time is the difference in the areas under their respective v-t graphs from the start time to that given time.
The area under the velocity-time graph represents the displacement of the object.
For object A, the area under the curve from time t = 0 to t = t2 is a triangle.
For object B, the area under the curve from time t = 0 to t = t2 is a combination of a triangle and a curved shape.
For object A, the displacement at time t2 is the area of the triangle formed by the velocity-time graph.
For object B, the displacement at time t2 is the area under the curve, which includes both the triangle and the curved shape.
At time t1, the displacement of object A is less than that of object B because the area under the curve for object B is larger.
At time t2, the displacement of object A is equal to that of object B because the areas under their respective curves are equal.
The objects are farthest apart when the difference in their displacements is the greatest.
This occurs at time t1, where the area under the curve for object B is significantly larger than that for object A.
Therefore, the two objects are farthest apart at time t1.
